cluster_classes.class_description: Steels prone to graphitization, including carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels, which lose strength and ductility due to microstructural changes.
cluster_classes.class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Graphitization affects carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels.

members.entity_description: Steels that do not have alloying elements intentionally added, but may contain small amounts of elements and are affected by graphitization under certain conditions.
A type of steel that undergoes graphitization at elevated temperatures.
A type of steel susceptible to graphitization, especially with up to 1% Mo.

cluster_classes.class_description: Steels engineered for high-temperature environments, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types, valued for strength and creep resistance and relevant to graphitization phenomena.
cluster_classes.class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Used for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

members.entity_description: A type of steel used for thick wall reactor vessels in petroleum refinery processes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes involving the transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules in steels at elevated temperatures, leading to loss of strength and ductility.
cluster_classes.class_group: Steel Graphitization and High-Temperature Steel Phenomena
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules.

members.entity_description: Change in microstructure of carbon and 0.5Mo steels causing loss of strength and ductility.
Result of carbide phase decomposition in steels at elevated temperatures, forming graphite nodules.

cluster_classes.class_description: The area of base metal near a weld that has not melted but has undergone changes in microstructure and mechanical properties due to welding heat.

members.entity_description: The portion of the base metal adjacent to a weld with altered microstructure and properties due to welding heat.

cluster_classes.class_description: Metals, alloys, and alloying elements known for their resistance to corrosion, including stainless steels, duplex stainless steels, nickel base alloys, titanium, and key elements such as chromium.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Duplex stainless steel and nickel base alloys are known for corrosion resistance.

members.entity_description: A family of stainless steels with a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure, known for its corrosion resistance, including Alloy 2205, 2304, and 2507.
A corrosion-resistant alloy of iron, chromium, and often nickel, known for its strength, durability, and resistance to oxidation, sulfidation, and other forms of corrosion.
A family of alloys with nickel as a major alloying element, including Alloys 200, 400, K-500, etc.
An alloying element in stainless steels that provides resistance to oxidation and corrosion.
Element added to steel to eliminate graphitization.
A strong, lightweight, and corrosion-resistant metal used in various applications.

cluster_classes.class_description: Low alloy steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance, not specifically defined by graphitization susceptibility.
cluster_classes.class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Graphitization affects carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels.

members.entity_description: Steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

args.new_description: Processes and mechanisms involving the transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules in steels at elevated temperatures, leading to loss of strength and ductility.
args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group for this class is currently inconsistent with the other steel/graphitization classes; unifying under 'Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena' clarifies the schema and connects related classes.

Entity 'chromium' (En_417e7d84) is described as an element added to steel to eliminate graphitization, which is directly relevant to graphitization-susceptible steels rather than general corrosion resistance; it fits better in 'Graphitization-Susceptible Steels'.
Class_Group is already appropriate for this class; no change needed except to confirm and lock in the grouping after entity reassignment.

args.new_description: Steels prone to graphitization, including carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels, as well as alloying elements (e.g., chromium) that inhibit graphitization.
args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Class now includes both susceptible steels and elements that inhibit graphitization (after entity reassignment); updating name and description for clarity.

args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group is already appropriate and consistent with related classes; confirming and locking in grouping.

args.new_class_group: Steel Types and High-Temperature Metallurgical Phenomena
args.justification: Class_Group is already appropriate and consistent with related classes; confirming and locking in grouping.
